solution.text:
Given numbers are :
_{{((16*j)+4)*i}}_ and _{{((4*j)+1)*i}}_
According to Euclid's division lemma:
c = dq + r
Step 1 : Since _{{((16*j)+4)*i}}_ > _{{((4*j)+1)*i}}_,
We apply the division lemma to _{{((16*j)+4)*i}}_ and _{{((4*j)+1)*i}}_
to get:
_{{((16*j)+4)*i}}_ = \(_{{((4*j)+1)*i}}_\times 3\) + _{{((3*j)+1)*i}}_
Step 2 : Since the remainder \(_{{((3*j)+1)*i}}_\neq 0\)
We apply the division lemma to :
_{{((4*j)+1)*i}}_ and _{{((3*j)+1)*i}}_
_{{((4*j)+1)*i}}_ = \(_{{((3*j)+1)*i}}_\times 1\) + _{{j*i}}_
Step 3 : Applying lemma until remainder becomes zero.
We consider the new divisor _{{((3*j)+1)*i}}_ and the new remainder _{{j*i}}_, and apply the division lemma to get:
_{{((3*j)+1)*i}}_ = \(_{{j*i}}_\times 3\) + _{i}_
Again,
We consider the new divisor _{{j*i}}_ and the new remainder _{i}_, and apply the division lemma to get:
_{{j*i}}_ = \(_{i}_\times _{j}_\) + 0
The remainder has now become zero, so our procedure stops.
Since the divisor at this stage is _{i}_, the HCF of _{{163*i}}_ and _{{21*i}}_ is _{i}_
Therefore, they can stand maximum in _{i}_ columns.

content.text: A school contain _{{((15*j)+4)*i}}_ students in class 9th and _{{((4*j)+1)*i}}_ students in 10th class.Both the group are to stand in same numbers of columns for the prayer.What is the maximum numbers of columns in which they can stand.
